author: pia.c.andrews
title: Regulation/legislation as code repo
description: Open access to rules is not currently universal. We believe this impedes democratic nation building, gov transparency & access to justice.

f6_assessments.q0: The solution statement is sensible in light of the problem statement and both are clearly written. The challenge seeks to accelerate the development of dApps that "cover foundational Registry solutions," with an emphasis on the storage/retrieval of vital records on the blockchain. The proposed open-source application is not a decentralized application per se, but it is designed to extract legal and regulatory data from a blockchain (i.e., "legislation as code") and determine regulatory compliance or user eligibility. As a development economist, I agree that there is a very real need globally for such systems, as they would speed-up access to critical services and attenuate the impact of corruption (especially in developing nations). Such systems can also be used to leverage the value of property registries because zoning/building regulations could be applied against specific land parcels stored on a blockchain. My primary concern is the size of the proposal's budget relative to the total allotment of funds for this challenge ($90,000 of the available $600,000). That said, breaking the project into two distinct phases (development of MVP and subsequent testing) may not be feasible. Overall, I strongly agree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1: The team is quite large and the members possess extensive experience in the fields of law, regulations, open government standards, and software development. The plan provided by the team is very detailed and clear, and given my experience working with various startups, the budget (although large) seems reasonable given the time and other resources required to successfully complete this project. It would have been nice if the team had provided an estimate of the total hours required to complete the two phases of the project (along with the implicit hourly pay rate), but given the scope of the work involved, that would be understandably difficult to accurately estimate. Overall, it is highly likely that this team will successfully develop the proposed project deliverables.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposed deliverables are very clear as are the KPIs provided by the team. The team does not address potential downside risk, but given the prior construction of the New Zealand legal database and the team's experience working with said data and the BetterRules project, failure to deliver a working product is unlikely. That said, there is greater uncertainty regarding the achievement of the KPIs, for which the downside risks are not addressed. Overall, I agree that this proposal provides sufficient information to assess its progress.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal seeks to solve the problem of lack of open access to government regulations and legislation by coding government rules into an open platform which partially aligns with the challenge goals but is not a foundational registry solution listed in the challenge.   
The proposal does a good job of articulating the value to Cardano ecosystem, and articulating how the solution scales to address future challenges.
The proposal could be improved by providing key metrics and goals that closely align with the challenge, and either selecting another challenge (Miscellaneous) or more closely aligning with this challenge's goals.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal articulates the feasibility aspects of team composition, budget is broken down and reasonable (more detail would improve), realistic timetable and plan, and detailed technical explanation of the solution.

The proposal's feasibility could be improved by evidence of experience (twitter accounts and proposal blurbs are insufficient), and a challenges and risks section.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal includes a roadmap, milestones, time horizon (very rough), a clear understandable description of the targeted problem and a detailed description of the solution that addresses the problem.
To improve the proposal include metrics/KPIs to measure proposal success.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is precisely the kind of thing we need, not just on Cardano but in this whole space. The more public goods, the better. Making regulation and legislation clear to those that wish to integrate their Dapps into the world and making the rules clear and open for all is a must-have to take advantage of our existing legal systems.
f6_assessments.q1: The team has in-depth experience and understanding of the problem and current systems we have in place; with that in mind, I have high confidence that we will see this implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: There is a clear description of the problem and solution here with identifiable measures of success based on the milestones. Key performance indicator's and what needs to be done is laid out clearly and on understandable grounds.

solution: A community managed open source platform for leg/reg as code for anyone to contribute to & build on + a legal eligibility tool to help ppl.
experience: A team of 8 with over  5+ yrs experience with rules as code, design, dev, gov platforms, leg/reg & intercultural practices
